Award.AwardTitle: Planning visit to Universidade Federal do Parana (UFPR), Brazil
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Jose D. Fuentes, Pennsylvania State University, OISE 1061712


Planning Visit to Universidade Federal do Paraná (UFPR), Brazil


This planning visit will establish joint research activities among investigators from Penn State University (Fuentes, Chameki) and Universidade do Paraná (Dias) in the general area of atmosphere-biosphere interactions. The team will draw from complementary experiences and expertise to develop research plans on the processes that influence spatial and temporal thermodynamic characteristics of the continental atmospheric boundary layer (ABL). Influences of the ABL state on the spatial and temporal distribution of airborne pollutants and their precursors will be considered. Numerical models designed to investigate emission, atmospheric transport and chemical processing of reactive chemical species and bio-aerosols will be indentified and discussed. During the visit, researchers will work together to design instrumented payload units for airborne platforms to investigate the spatial distribution of trace gases in the ABL. The objective is to design sufficiently light gas sensors to be interfaced with onboard data acquisition units. Numerical models that emerge from these data will be tested and validated for different landscapes.

This visit will lay the foundation for new research collaborations between US and Brazilian scientists with complementary expertise in the study of atmosphere-biosphere interactions. Processes that control the spatial distribution of gases in the lower atmosphere have immediate implications for predicting air quality. Collaborations between these research groups will create new and unique opportunities to investigate environmental processes with emerging technologies. The PI has extensive mentoring experience and the research program that evolves from this visit is likely to create substantial student involvement. Moreover, the co-PI is a new investigator and he and two graduate students will accompany the team to Brazil.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

This project contributed to the development of collaborative research activities pursued by investigators from Penn State University (United States) and Universidade Federal do Paraná (Brazil). Two faculty members, two graduate students, and one undergraduate student from Penn State University spent ten days at the Universidade Federal do Paraná discussing research results and identifying joint research opportunities in the general area of biosphere-atmosphere interactions. Students and faculty members exchanged research interests and results. Each team highlighted the active research activities via oral presentations made to resident faculty, graduates, and undergraduates. Students provided updates on the progress made with existing projects associated with thesis research. Faculty members presented results of current projects in their respective laboratories. Several classes of undergraduates were invited to the oral presentations, which were given in both English and Portuguese. Managers representing several Brazilian funding agencies participated in the discussions on research priorities. Visiting scientists took a full-day trip to participate in field activities related to the use of unmanned aerial vehicles to investigate air turbulence and transport of heat in the lower atmosphere.

This project generated several notable outcomes. The planned research activities resulted in one journal publication (Boundary-Layer Meteorology 144:113-135, 2012) involving authors from Penn State University and Universidade Federal do Paraná. The developed collaborative research agenda served as the basis to prepare one joint research proposal submitted for funding consideration to the US Department of Energy and Brazilian funding agencies. A second joint research proposal was under development for funding consideration by US and Brazilian agencies. Graduate student training at Penn State University and Universidade Federal do Paraná represented a core component of the developed research proposals. One graduate student from Universidade Federal do Paraná came to spend one year at Penn State University and pursued research in the area of surface-atmosphere interactions. Funded by a Brazilian agency, a doctoral student chose to pursue her studies at Penn State University in response to the research opportunities presented and discussed while the Penn Sate university team visited Universidade Federal do Paraná. This project provided unprecedented opportunities to three Penn State University students to participate in international research. Students presented their own research results to fellow Brazilian peers. They also learned novel research methodologies involving unnamed aerial vehicles to investigate the characteristics of air turbulence and transport of heat in the lower atmosphere. Two of the Penn State University students who participated in this project decided to pursue doctoral studies largely in response to the international experiences gained as part of this project.
